title: Home of Bayern
text: Despite their status as one of the true heavyweights of European football, Bayern Munich lacked an iconic stadium until 2005 when the Allianz Arena opened its doors. Built in time for the 2006 World Cup, the Arena was designed to give Bavaria a sporting temple to be proud of. Seating 71,000 spectators, and famous for selling out most matches before the season even begins, the first battle you may face when trying to see Bayern's home first-hand is the one of picking up a ticket. Personally I was tactical in my approach, opting to go for a midweek cup game against lower-league Heidenheim, the week after a Champions League tie and days before a practical league-decider against Borussia Dortmund. While this mean I could be a ticket first-hand (through Bayern's excellent online service) I was still pleasantly surprised by the crowd they drew in for such a tie (admittedly, due to Germany's lax laws on segregation, a lot of Heidenheim fans had made the relatively short journey too) If you are trying to gain tickets for a game that appears sold out don't fret. Bayern do offer an official secondary market service on their website, and tickets are usually avaialble either on the day via touts outside or on secondary selling site Viagogo. The risk with these is paying inflated rates, but I guess that comes entirely down to how much you're willing to pay. On the subject of ticket prices, I do think it is important to address one of the almost buzzwords of German football and shatter some notions; while it is true that tickets start at ‚Ç¨15 for the standing section, don't expect to get your hands on one of them - they go first, to your actual fans, rightly so. You'll be paying around ¬£25-35 face value for one of the tickets, which, when you take into account at one stage recently it has cost ¬£27 to see Rangers v Albion Rovers, isn't really bad at all, and is what I'd class as the norm. Getting to the stadium is a fairly simple task; Despite being well out with the city itself, the Allianz is serviced by a Metro stop which is followed by around a 10 minute walk. No complaints here. As with most Continental stadiums, your ticket first gains you entrance to a gated off concourse outside the actual structure itself, where you can buy food, visit the Bayern Megastore or just bask in the majesty of the place. It is worth noting that while there are Official Bayern merchandise booths outside the concourse, there are surprisingly view unofficial merchants (1 as you come off the Metro) so don't expect any cheaper scarves or merch! As you'd expect pints are served inside the stadium, so that's one of the hallowed selling points of German football definitely true! Also worth taking stock of is not to jump the gun and get food from the lower level food stalls, which offer a fairly sparse selection compared to what is available once you actually enter the ground. On the subject of the actual stadium itself, the Allianz is a wonderful blend of contemporary design and traditional 'feel'. It's plastic, light-up, colour changing exterior is what it's best known for (and don't try pretend it isn't cool) but once you actually venture up the stairs you find yourself in a theatre built for watching football: great views, and an even better atmosphere generated by Bayern's support, which is easier said than done given the high amount of tourists who earmark this as a must see. I realise the hypocrisy there but I do at least try to join in language permitting! I'm usually loathe to rate a stadium's atmosphere based upon one game, but watching Bayern play a 2nd tier outfit in a cup game a week removed from a Champions League exit actually told me a lot: Their fans are fantastic. Genuinely. Lively, loud and above all else fun, it's hard to fault the atmosphere they generated (big shout out to the Heidenheim support too on that front) and it does nothing but whet the appetite to visit on a Champions League or big Bundesliga date. Sadly I wasn't in Munich long enough to take in the tour, but I am assured it covers all the necessary bases. I couldn't recommend a trip to the Allianz to any football fan enough. Gorgeous stadium, great crowd and generally everything I look for in a day at the game. As I say you might need to pay slightly over the odds to gain a ticket, but I've heard tickets to an English Premier League game can start at ¬£50 a head, so I suppose realistically how much you pay comes down to personal circumstance. I'd definitely go back, and wouldn't mind paying slightly over the odds because I know how good it is.

text: My husband and I decided to go to the stadium on our first afternoon in Munich. Taking the train from Marienplatz is easy- the stop you need to get off at is marked with a soccer ball. You can see the stadium from the train station but it's still about a 15 minute walk. Follow the signs to the right of the building and head up to the ticket counter where you get your combo ticket for the museum and tour. The tour is so fun; you sit in a few different sections of the stadium, see the locker room, walk the tunnel like the players do, and learn all kinds of fun stuff along the way. We had an amazing tour guide who made lots of fun jokes. The museum has tons of Bayern Munich artifacts, you could spend a few hours in there alone. If you want to go on game days you have to have a ticket also for the game. Know that the area between the train station and the stadium is not well lit on non game days so if you are going to be walking through there after the sun sets use the flashlight on your phone. It was SO DARK. and maybe don't walk there alone.
